text:
That’s a deadly cone snail
coming up on the right.

And the little fellow
is, a jumping snail —
look at it go!

The snail increases its
oxygen use up to six times
to make those leaps.

And Norwegian and
Australian researchers

wanted to know how the snail
would do in the warmer,
more acid seas

that are predicted
because of climate change.

Scientists think
those conditions

could damage coral reefs, where
these and other snails live.

They needed to make the little
snails jump, which they do,

when they smell a nearby
predator, like a cone snail.

So the researchers
collected eau de cone snail,

then they added it to a
chamber called a respirometer
with a jumping snail inside.

They recorded the jumps and
monitored the oxygen taken up
from the water.

The snails did great, no
matter whether the water was
warm, or acid, or both.

That’s good news —
even if warmer seas

could affect many other
aspects of snail life.
